nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by centering research design, natural experiments, and formalizing the causal content of instrumental variables (LATE) to produce more credible causal inference
Design-based empirical approach: emphasizing research design, explicit identifying assumptions, and use of natural/quasi-experiments to construct credible control groups and validate causal claims

Imbens and Angrist formalized IV in a potential outcomes framework and proved the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) theorem clarifying what IV estimates identify under random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance
Card pioneered empirical applications using natural experiments and careful control groups that produced surprising, influential findings on minimum wages, immigration, and education

Design-based methods include randomized controlled trials (where feasible), natural/quasi-experiments, difference-in-differences, regression discontinuity, shift-share instruments, and researcher-collected or linked administrative data tailored to the design

Natural experiments and careful control group construction increase internal validity by making the source of treatment variation interpretable and allowing direct tests (e.g., balance and placebo checks) of identifying assumptions

Design-based emphasis draws a distinction between identifying assumptions (central, often institutional) and ancillary modeling choices (covariate controls, weighting), focusing robustness analysis on the latter
Regression discontinuity and fuzzy RD are closely related to IV: when compliance is imperfect, the RD jump identifies a LATE for compliers near the threshold

LATE interpretation: the IV estimand identifies the average treatment effect for compliers (the subpopulation whose treatment status changes with the instrument), not necessarily the average treatment effect for the whole population
Separating assumptions: random assignment (statistical) vs exclusion and monotonicity (substantive) clarifies what must be justified by institutional knowledge vs what can be tested empirically
Implication for empirical practice: LATE motivates combining design-based estimates with structural models or alternative designs to address external validity and synthesize evidence across settings
A design-based focus improved credibility and replicability of empirical findings and encouraged collection/linking of targeted data and researcher-collected surveys to match designs

Mariel boatlift (Card 1990): using Miami as treated city and a constructed control group of similar cities, Card found little effect of a large low-skill immigrant inflow on native wages and employment, suggesting limited local labor market impacts in that episode

New Jersey minimum wage study (Card and Krueger 1994): a border diﬀerence-in-diﬀerences survey of fast-food restaurants found no employment decline after a 20% minimum wage increase, contradicting simple competitive model predictions

Quarter-of-birth IV (Angrist and Krueger 1991) and related IVs: narrow instrument-induced variation (e.g., birthdays) yielded an estimated return to schooling of about 10% per year for compliers, illustrating IV identifies LATE for marginal students

Other experimental/quasi-experimental results: draft lottery IV (Angrist 1990) found a roughly 15% earnings penalty for military service among compliers; lottery winner study (Imbens et al. 2001) found modest negative labor supply eﬀects of unearned income; Self-Sufficiency Project RCT (Card and Hyslop 2005) showed temporary earnings subsidies altered short-run employment dynamics with limited long-run wage effects

Limitation and caveat: design-based IV and natural experiment estimates can lack external validity due to treatment effect heterogeneity and narrow complier populations; synthesizing across designs or imposing credible structural assumptions is necessary to generalize results
